lesson.title: Telling Stories with Tableau
lesson.summary: In this final lesson you learn how to build interactive Tableau dashboards and tell impactful stories using data.

atoms.text:
Now that you can make plots with Tableau, it's time use them to communicate with your data.

First, I'll cover exploring your data to get a sense of what's going on. For example, it's good to know how variables are distributed and if any thing seems wrong with the data. You'll also want to look for patterns and interesting questions. 

You'll also want to share your data with others. Tableau is great for creating interactive dashboards and stories that let your readers play your data on their own. Dashboards collect views into one idea. Stories are narrated walkthroughs of views and dashboards. With dashboards and stories, your job is to facilitate the interaction with the data story you are trying to tell.

You already can do a ton with Tableau to explore a dataset. The ideas in this lesson will help you with tackling a dataset for the first time and putting your final products together. There are five purposes of this lesson before you move onto your project and complete your Tableau journey here at Udacity. 1. We have been working with a single dataset, but it is important you can feel comfortable with lots of different types of data, so you will gain that practice in this lesson.

2. You will learn about **dashboards**, which allow you to analyze multiple sheets all at the same time. And even build filters that act over all the sheets at once.

3. You will combine items 1 and 2 above to create dashboards for some new datasets. Donâ€™t worry, we will do this together to build your confidence. That way you get some practice for you tackle the project.

4. You will learn about **stories**, a feature of tableau that allows you to link together your worksheets in dashboards to give an audience a well rounded grasp of your insights.

5. Finally, we will point you to some **additional resources** for you to continue learning and keep your Tableau skills fresh.

You will be using a few new datasets to complete the questions in this lesson, so they are provided in the Resources tab.
Similar data to the video here is provided under the **Supporting Materials** at the bottom of the page.

### Hierarchies & Filters

All of the information you saw in the previous lesson is important, but two things I find myself using **ALL THE TIME** are **Hierarchies & Filters**.  These two components wow your audiences, and take the interactivity with your visual to a new level.

Hopefully this video served as a great reminder.  You will see both hierarchies & filters used pretty extensively in the next sections on dashboards.

tasks: Download the **Movie** data from the resources and open Tableau.
From **Connect** on the left side choose `Text file`. Navigate to the `movie_metadata.csv` and select.
Create a new worksheet.  Drag the **Movie Title** onto the **Genres** to create a hierarchy.
Move your **new hierarchy** to the `Rows`.  Move **Gross** to the `Columns`.
Drill down to look at the break up in this category.
Quiz 1 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for the next list!

question.prompt:
### Quiz 1

The result isn't great here at comparing movies in terms of sales.  Which of the below are reasons for this?  (Select all that apply.)

answers.text: The **Genres** field breaks up movies into very specific and not always useful categories.
It would be better for comparison to simply have one genre for each movie.
There are so many genres it might be easiest to look at one at a time, but some movies are in a genre of their own, which also isn't helpful.

tasks: In order to improve this visual, let's use the next steps to `split` the **Genre** and add a `Filter`.
Click back to the `Data Source` in the bottom left of the screen.  Right click the **Genres** column.
Select `Custom Split...`.  Use the`|` as the separator, and select `OK`. This should create **Genres - Split 1**.
Move back to the worksheet.
Create a new hierarchy by dragging **Movie Title** onto the **Genres - Split 1** to create a hierarchy.
Remove the original hierarchy from the `Rows`, and add your new hierarchy to the `Rows`.
Add your new hierarchy to the Filters table as well.  Select the drop down and `Show Filter`.
Quiz 2 below.  A screenshot of my visual is provided at the bottom, but you will need your own to complete the quiz.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for the next list below!

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 2

Pair each movie with its corresponding description.

concepts.text: Top grossing `Fantasy` movie.
The only `Game-Show` available.
Top grossing `Adventure` movie.
Top grossing `Animation` movie.

tasks: Change the name of the sheet to `Gross Sales` and create a new worksheet.
Create a `Calculated Field` of **Net** as **[Gross] - [Budget]**.
Move **Net** to the `Columns` and the same hierarchy you used in the original plot to the `Rows` and `Filters` table.
Quiz 3-4 below
Click on the hierarchy filter dropdown in the `Filters` table to select `Apply to Worksheets` using `All Using Related Data Sources`
Quiz 5 below.  A screenshot of my visual is provided at the bottom, but you will need your own to complete. the quiz.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for the next list!

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 3

Use your visual to match each **Genre** to the corresponding description.

concepts.text: The highest net profit genre.
This genre netted 2.8 Billion.
This genre lost the most money.
There wasn't any financial info on this genre.

question.prompt:
### Quiz 4

What is the issue with the dashboard you created?

answers.text: When I update one filter, it only acts on the sheet I created it on.
When I update one filter, it works on all the sheets incorrectly.

question.prompt:
### Quiz 5

Does your filter now update all the worksheets?

atoms.text:
Below are two links to the same data but with different file types.

The first file is a csv and you should try to use this one first. If it works great, continue with the exercise! If you have difficulty importing it into Tableau try using the second link which is an xlsx file. If you are still unable to import either file into Tableau please reach out to support@udacity.com

concepts.title: Video: Building Dashboards & Stories with Trina

atoms.text:
You can find the data for this video at the bottom of this concept as well as in the **Resources**.

This data set has been cut down from the one used in the video so that it is easier to work with.

concepts.title: Text: General Notes for Building Data Dashboards with Trina

atoms.text:
### Quick Note

The notes below are the general workflow for creating a dashboard.  If you are ready to practice for yourself, feel free to skip ahead two concepts to the quiz and simply use this as a reference if you need it.

# Dashboards

Dashboards are used to collect multiple sheets that exhibit one idea. For instance, [here is an example](http://www.tableau.com/stories/gallery/sales-and-opportunities) of a dashboard about sales opportunities found in Salesforce data. You can see in the dashboard that clicking on one view filters the data on the other views. This is one of the excellent interactive features you can use to let viewers explore your data. Dashboards are also great for building reports from various views that you want to keep track of every day or week.

Tableau has a whole set of great dashboards in their [gallery](https://public.tableau.com/en-us/s/gallery). Check them out for inspiration.

To create a new dashboard, click on the "New Dashboard" button in the bottom bar.
This brings on the dashboard interface. You create the dashboard by dragging sheets from the left bar into the canvas.

Tableau has a great set of tutorial videos on building dashboards if you want some additional information:

* [Getting started with dashboards and stories](http://www.tableau.com/learn/tutorials/on-demand/getting-started-dashboards-and-stories)
* [Building dashboards](http://www.tableau.com/learn/tutorials/on-demand/building-dashboard)
* [Documentation on dashboards](http://onlinehelp.tableau.com/current/pro/desktop/en-us/help.htm#dashboards.html%3FTocPath%3DPresent%2520Your%2520Work%7CDashboards%7C_____0) 

In the quiz on the next concept, you will get practice on your own building dashboards.

concepts.title: Text: General Notes for Building Stories

atoms.text:
### Quick Note

The notes below are the general workflow for creating a story.  If you are ready to practice for yourself, feel free to skip ahead to the next concept to the quiz and simply use this as a reference if you need it.

## Stories

Stories are great for a narrated walkthrough of the discoveries you made in your data. They are similar to dashboards in that you create sheets, then drag the sheets to the story. However, each sheet is displayed separately along with narrative text in sequential series.

Below is a story I made looking into why the Global Superstore is losing money in some countries. You can download [the workbook here](https://s3.amazonaws.com/content.udacity-data.com/courses/ud1006/Poor+Markets+Story.twbx) or from the public story.

<iframe src="https://public.tableau.com/shared/2MFNHMNK3?:showVizHome=no&:embed=true"
 width="750" height="600"></iframe>

From this story, you can see that deep discounts are responsible for negative profits in a fairly large number of countries. The discounts aren't really helping growth there and the negative profits are getting worse over time. It might be a good idea to stop offering as many discounts there, or to leave the markets completely.

## Creating a story

To create a new story, click on the "New Story" button at the bottom.
This brings up the story interface:
Here you drag a sheet to the view to create the first story point. In the grey box, you can add text to start the narrative. To create the next story point, click on "New Blank Point".

Stories allow you to give a personal flair to your presentation.  This can be nice if you have a presentation that can occur all in Tableau, but often there are other parts of a presentation that you might want to use another tool.  In which case, Tableau might not be the best option for these cases.

Additional information on stories can be found here:

*  [This tutorial video](http://www.tableau.com/learn/tutorials/on-demand/story-points) from Tableau.
* [Documentation is here.](https://onlinehelp.tableau.com/current/pro/online/mac/en-us/stories.html)

You will get hands on practice in the next concept.

concepts.title: Quiz: Building Dashboards & Stories with Trina

tasks: Download the `asylum_seekers...` data.
Open Tableau.  Connect to the data using the `Text file` extension.
Change the `Value` column to `Number of Asylum Seekers`.
Click to a new worksheet.
Move **Origin** to the Columns.  Move **Number of Asylum Seekers** to the Rows.
Quiz 1 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for the next list.

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 1

Match each of the descriptions to the correct answer.

concepts.text: Most refugees arrived from what country?
Of the countries that had any refugees, which country had the least?
The value associated with the number of refugees from Sri Lanka.
The number of refugees from Switzerland.

tasks: Create a filter for the **Date**, which you can do by dragging to the Filters table
In the popup asking how do you want to filter on [Date]? Select Year. Then click ok on the next pop up.
Select from the drop down on Date in the filter box `Show filter...`.
Change the filter to a `Single Value (list)`.
Quiz 2 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You're ready to take on the next list.

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 2

Match each Country to the correct corresponding description.

concepts.text: This country had the most refugees in 2007.
This country had the most refugees in 2005.
This country had the most refugees in 2002.
This country has the largest number of refugees across all years.

tasks: Create a new worksheet.
Double click **Country** and move **Number of Asylum Seekers** to Color in the Marks table.
Notice our data isn't exactly the same as Trina's data.
Quiz 3 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for your next set of tasks.

question.prompt:
### Quiz 3

Which country took in the most refugees?

tasks: Create a new worksheet.
Change the **Date** to continuous.
Move **Date** to the `Columns` and **Number of Asylum Seekers** to the `Rows`.
Drill down to the month level.
Quiz 4 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  In the next tasks, you will put your worksheets together into a dashboard!

question.prompt:
### Quiz 4

Which of these months below had the the largest number of refugees?

tasks: Create a new dashboard.
Drag each of your worksheets onto the dashboard.
Change the size width to fit your screen.
Use the drop down in the top right of each of your worksheets to remove all the titles.
Click the drop down in the map worksheet to select `Use as filter`.
Click the drop down on your `Year of Date` filter to select `Apply to Worksheets` > `All Using Related Data Sources`.
Quiz 5 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You have a really cool dashboard now!  One last set of steps to turn this into a story.

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 5 

Match each value to the appropriate description.

concepts.text: The top country seekers traveled to in 2016.
The top country seekers are moving from in 2016.
The month for the highest number of refugees in 2001.
The top country that seekers are moving from in 2006.
The top country for seekers to travel to in 2006.

tasks: Select the story button at the bottom of Tableau.
Drag a worksheet into the main screen and add a caption.
Click and drag an additional worksheet to the right of your first.  Add a second caption.
Click and drag your dashboard to the right of those two worksheets.
Click the presentation tool at the top, so you can play your story.
Here is the story I created from our data here: https://public.tableau.com/profile/josh2979#!/vizhome/MyFirstTableauStory_0/Story1?publish=yes.
Quiz 6 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job! You know how to create worksheets, dashboards, and stories in Tableau.  The next sections will just be practice with these new tools, but you know everything you need to build `all things Tableau`.

question.prompt:
### Quiz 6

Select all the below that are true.

answers.text: Tableau stories should be used for all data visualization cases.
Stories may **not** be useful if you are creating elements to a presentation outside of Tableau.
Stories can incorporate both dashboards and worksheets.
You are now capable of building `all the things` in Tableau.

tasks: Load the dataset using the Excel connector.
Change the `Date` to a `Date` datatype in Tableau using the upper left drop down for the column.
Create a new worksheet.
From the **Team** drop down change to `Geographical Role` > `Country/Region`.
Double click the new geographical **Team**.
Drag the **Goals** to the `Color` portion of the `Marks` table, and select the map with shading.
Create a filter using **Year** and show the filter for your visualization.
Quiz 1 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for the next steps!

complex_prompt.text:
### Quiz 1

Match each country to the corresponding description.

concepts.text: Which country has the most goals for all years?
Which country had the most goals in 1930?
Which country had the most goals in 2006?
Which country had the most goals in 1998?

tasks: Create a new worksheet.
Create a map similar to the previous worksheet.
Create a group for all of the countries in North and South America.  Make sure to use all the data when you create the group.
Re-create the map based on these two groups, rather than by country.
Color by the SUM of the **Goals** and add a Filter for **Year**.
You can check your map looks like mine at the bottom of this concept.
Quiz 2 below.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  This one was tricky!

question.prompt:
### Quiz 2

Which of the following years were years where North and South America outscored the rest of the world. (Check all that apply).

tasks: Move **Date** to the Columns (Make sure this has been changed to a date datatype).
Move **Goals** to the Rows.
Color by your **Team (group)**.
Change your plot on `Show Me` to a Line Chart.
Quiz 3 below.  You can see this plot at the bottom of this concept.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You are ready for your final tasks!

question.prompt:
### Quiz 3

Which of the below are true regarding your new plot?

answers.text: It is much easier to use the line plot to see which years which group had more points.
We can technically use either plot to get the same information.
The line plot makes it easier to see the overall trends in goals scored by each group.

tasks: Create a new dashboard.
Put your datasets working with the two grouped data on the same dashboard (you should have two worksheets).
Assure the filter applies for both worksheets.
Remove the titles.
Save your dashboard to Tableau Public.
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice job!  You have completed the final case study!

atoms.text:
Solutions:

* [Quiz 1](https://public.tableau.com/profile/josh2979#!/vizhome/GoalsbyCountry/Sheet2?publish=yes)
* [Quiz 2](https://public.tableau.com/profile/josh2979#!/vizhome/GoalsbyGroup/Sheet1?publish=yes)
* [Quiz 3](https://public.tableau.com/profile/josh2979#!/vizhome/Lines_13/Sheet3?publish=yes)
* [Final Dashboard](https://public.tableau.com/profile/josh2979#!/vizhome/DashboardSolution/Dashboard1?publish=yes)

### Lesson Recap

In this lesson, you learned how to use Tableau with both `.xls` files and `.csv` files by analyzing:

* The **Movie** data.
* The **Asylum Seekers** data.
* The **World Cup** data.

You completed **three mini projects** with each dataset that required a strong understanding of worksheets, dashboards, and stories in Tableau.

_____

Additionally, you learned how to put together:
* Tableau `Dashboards`
* Tableau `Stories`

You are now ready to **TAKE ON THE PROJECT!**

______

Though there is always more to learn with every tool, you are able to tackle tons of questions using Tableau!  I cannot wait to see what you create for your projects.
